channel.title: 60-Second Civics Podcast
channel.itunes:author: Center for Civic Education
channel.itunes:subtitle: 60-Second Civics Podcast
channel.description:
60-Second Civics is a daily podcast that provides a quick and convenient way for listeners to learn about our nation's government, the Constitution, and our history. The podcast explores themes related to civics and government, the constitutional issues behind the headlines, and the people and ideas that formed our nation's history and government.
60-Second Civics is produced by the Center for Civic Education. The show's content is primarily derived from the Center's education for democracy curricula, including We the People: The Citizen and the Constitution, Project Citizen, Foundations of Democracy, and Elements of Democracy.
channel.itunes:summary:

60-Second Civics is produced by the Center for Civic Education. The show's content is primarily derived from the Center's education for democracy curricula, including We the People: The Citizen and the Constitution, Project Citizen, Foundations of Democracy, and Elements of Democracy.
channel.itunes:keywords: education, civics, civic education, service learning, government, law, history, constitution, constitution day, local government, state government, We the People, Project Citizen, Civitas, Foundations of Democracy, violence prevention, judiciary

item.title: 60-Second Civics: Episode 2510, Civic virtue cannot be relied upon
item.description:
Is civic virtue enough to allow a republic to survive? The Federalists said it wasn't.
Center for Civic Education

item.title: 60-Second Civics: Episode 2509, Survival in a large republic
item.description:
How could democracy survive in a large, diverse nation? James Madison thought he knew the answer.
Center for Civic Education

item.description:

Center for Civic Education

item.title: 60-Second Civics: Episode 2140, The Philadelphia Convention, Part 4: Founders who did not attend the Philadelphia Convention
item.description:
Jefferson, Adams, Paine, Henry, and Hancock did not attend the Philadelphia Convention, but for different reasons.
Center for Civic Education

The Federalists argued that the Constitution represented a "new science of politics."

item.description:

item.title: 60-Second Civics: Episode 2504, Federalist strategy
item.description:
Federalist strategy was to hold state ratifying conventions as soon as possible so that Anti-Federalists would not have enough time to organize.
Center for Civic Education

item.title: 60-Second Civics: Episode 2503, Arguments for a bill of rights
item.description:
State governments had bills of rights, so why didn't the federal government?
Center for Civic Education

item.title: 60-Second Civics: Episode 2502, Vague and general powers are dangerous
item.description:
The Anti-Federalists believed that the lack of a bill of rights in the Constitution would results in basic rights of the people being stripped away.
Center for Civic Education

item.title: 60-Second Civics: Episode 2500, Anti-Federalist criticisms of checks and balances
item.description:
It's our 2,500th episode! Today we learn about some powerful Anti-Federalist critiques of the system of checks and balances.
Center for Civic Education

item.title: 60-Second Civics: Episode 2499, Anti-Federalist arguments about the presidency and courts
item.description:
The Anti-Federalists argued that both the president and the federal courts would have too much power under the Constitution.
Center for Civic Education

The Anti-Federalists were concerned that the Constitution gave too much power to Congress.

item.description:
Overall, George Washington felt that the Anti-Federalists had contributed to the country.
Center for Civic Education

item.description:

Center for Civic Education

item.title: 60-Second Civics: Episode 2484, A compromise over slavery
item.description:
